list_page_teaser: American Presidents, just like any other group of individuals, have different personalities.  Learn how the images of some popular and recent presidents reflect their idealism, decisiveness, and other qualities.
description_html:
Which politicians – ☺ if any ☺ – are your favorites? How does your personality compare to theirs?

This gallery contains a few spiritual portraits of our presidents from the 1900s. If you know your four-letter type, perhaps you can see similarities between your personality and that of your favorite president — assuming you have one!
story_html:
I frequently wonder whether an individual's personality type has any bearing on how they lean politically. As an idealist, I am definitely biased toward idealistic presidents, such as Jefferson and Lincoln.

If this topic interests you, check out David Keirsey's book Presidential Temperament. It covers this topic in depth!

I will be adding portraits to this gallery soon. To keep up to date and learn when I post new images, follow this site on social media or join the SeeOurMinds.com email list!

image_list.title: Richard Milhous Nixon
image_list.subtitle_html: 37th President of the USA — Jan. 20, 1969 to Aug. 9, 1974
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Richard Nixon's spiritual portrait shows he is very logical and a bit pragmatic.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Green in Richard Nixon's spiritual portrait represents his dominant personality trait, his strong preference for making logical rather than emotional decisions.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  He demonstrated this preference in the Nixon Doctrine, which assured allies the US would honor its treaties and provide a nuclear shield, while addressing both waning support for the Vietnam War in the US and budget concerns about similar costly endeavors in other countries.
image_list.explain_aux: The Yellow in Richard Nixon's spiritual portrait represents his auxiliary personality trait, his fairly strong preference for seeing a world of facts rather than ideas.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  He demonstrated this preference in the way he adopted a more realistic, pragmatic view of the war in Vietnam than many of his predecessors did.
image_list.story_intro_html:
Born in Yorba Linda, California on January 9, 1913, Richard Milhous Nixon became the 37th President at the age of 56 in 1969. Even though Nixon was born two years after Ronald Reagan, he became president over a decade before Reagan.

As the large amounts of Green in their spiritual portraits show, Presidents Nixon and Regan had similar personalities. And as the other colors show — Nixon's Yellow as opposed to Reagan's Blue in particular — there were differences.

From Anti-Communist Congressman to Eisenhower's VP

After serving in the Navy during World War II, Richard Nixon was caught up in the anti-communist fervor that prevailed in the United States in the late 1940s and early 1950s.

Nixon was a member of the House Un-American Activities Committee (HUAC) and earned the moniker Tricky Dick for his aggressively anti-Communist campaign tactics in the Senate election in California in 1950. His anti-communist stance, plus his young age and political base in California, helped influence Eisenhower to choose Nixon as his running mate in the 1952 Presidential election.

Richard Nixon served two terms as Vice President for Dwight D. Eisenhower, from 1953 to 1961. Entering office as the 36th Vice President at the age of 40, Nixon was the second-youngest person to hold that office, the youngest being John C. Breckinridge, who took the office at age 36.

From Loser to Law-and-Order Candidate

Richard Nixon lost the very close presidential election in 1960 to John Fitzgerald Kennedy, and lost again to Pat Brown when he ran for governor of California in 1962, and subsequently announced he was leaving politics.

I leave you gentleman now. You will now write it; you will interpret it; that's your right. But as I leave you I want you to know — just think how much you're going to be missing. You don't have Nixon to kick around any more, because, gentlemen, this is my last press conference.
 — Richard Nixon, in a press conference given after losing the election for Governor of California, November 7, 1962.

Nixon tried leaving politics and joined a law firm in New York City. But politics was in his blood and he continued campaigning for Republican Party candidates in the 1964 and 1966 elections.

Richard Nixon returned to politics and ran for President again in 1968. The anti-Vietnam War demonstrations were at their height, and as his fellow Republican Ronald Reagan would do when running for re-election as Governor of California in 1970, Nixon leveraged this distruption by campaigning as a law-and-order candidate.

Peacemaker

Nixon won the fairly close, three-way presidential election in 1968. It's important to realize his anti-communist, law-and-order stance does not imply he was an enemy of peace. It may surprise some people but his goal, in fact, was for history to consider him a peacemaker.

As the Green in his spiritual portrait shows, Richard Nixon preferred logic to emotion. So although both he and the protesters wanted peace, he differed from them in that he was not inclined to get all emotional about it.

What kind of nation we will be, what kind of world we will live in, whether we shape the future in the image of our hopes, is ours to determine by our actions and our choices. The greatest honor history can bestow is the title of peacemaker.
 — Richard Nixon in his First Inaugural Address, January 20, 1969.

In the Remarks on Being Reelected to the Presidency speech he gave on November 7, 1972, Nixon would clarify this somewhat, saying it is important to work for peace with honor.

Crisis: Watergate

When Richard Nixon ran for re-election in the Presidential election of 1972, he won by a landslide. Garnering over 60% of the popular vote, he carried all but one state.

Like many other two-term presidents, Nixon fell prey to the second-term curse — a superstition that may betray the all-too-human tendency towards confirmation bias. In Nixon's case, the curse actually came true.

Shortly after the start of Richard Nixon's second term, the Watergate scandal broke. Unbeknownst to Nixon, people in his administration were committing criminal acts, including breaking into the offices of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist and the Democratic National Committee.

As the Yellow in Richard Nixon's spiritual portrait shows, he is more pragmatic than idealistic. In this case, his pragmatic reaction when he learned about these break-ins ultimately caused his downfall.

When Pragmatism Goes Wrong

Rather than do the right thing and come clean, when Richard Nixon first learned about these crimes, he tried to cover them up. But one thing led to another, and he found himself caught in his own web of deceit.

In Nixon's mind — at least initially — both Republicans and Democrats were guilty of shady tactics, and he was simply doing the right thing by supporting the people who worked for him.

I know that it can be very easy, under the intensive pressures of a campaign, for even well-intentioned people to fall into shady tactics — to rationalize this on the grounds that what is at stake is of such importance to the Nation that the end justifies the means. And both of our great parties have been guilty of such tactics in the past.
 — From Richard Nixon's Address to the Nation About the Watergate Investigations, April 30, 1973.

In Nixon's mind, the ends justifies the means and — as he would later tell David Frost — when the President does it, that means that it is not illegal.

Not a Crook

Although Richard Nixon did not participate in or even know about these specific criminal activities until after the fact, his actions led to Watergate Special Counsel Archibald Cox subpeonaing tape recordings from the White House, in an effort to find out who was guilty.

Faced with rapidly declining popularity, Nixon addressed the nation with his infamous claim, I'm not a crook:

I want to say this to the television audience. I made my mistakes, but in all of my years of public life, I have never profited, never profited from public service. I have earned every cent. And in all of my years of public life, I have never obstructed justice. And I think, too, that I can say that in my years of public life, that I welcome this kind of examination because people have got to know whether or not their President is a crook. Well, I'm not a crook. I've earned everything I've got.
 — From Richard Nixon's televised address to the people of the United States, broadcast on National Public Radio, November 17, 1973.

Although Richard Nixon was willing to use politically shady tactics, he was not totally bereft of morality. His pragmatism in helping to cover up the criminal acts may have caused his downfall, but he did his best to maintain some sense of personal honor.

Ending the War in Vietnam

In the Nixon Doctrine the President set forth in 1969, he called for Vietnamization of the region. Nixon hoped that by using troops from the South Vietnamese Army (ARVN) he could end America's involvement in the region.

In both of his terms as president, Richard Nixon worked with Henry Kissinger, his National Security Advisor, on a number of fronts to end America's involvement in the Vietnam War. Specifically they:

  • Used diplomacy by supporting the Paris Accords started in 1968 by then-President Lyndon Johnson.
  • Used the Air Force to carpet bomb Vietnam's neighbor Cambodia in 1969-1970 and North Vietnam itself from May through October of 1972, culminating in the Christmas Bombings in late December of 1972.
  • Even tried using a bit of implied irrationality to scare the communist-supported North Vietnamese into giving up.

The Paris Peace Accords included North Vietnam, South Vietnam, and South Vietnam's underground government, but encountered frequent stalemates. Determined to be a peacemaker, the tenacious, decisive Nixon refused to give up.

In a speech Nixon gave upon being reelected in 1972, he uses the word peace six times in a single sentence:

We are united Americans — North, East, West, and South, both parties — in our desire for peace, peace with honor, the kind of a peace that will last, and we are moving swiftly toward that great goal, not just in Vietnam, but a new era of peace in which the old relationships between the two super powers, the Soviet Union and the United States, and between the world's most populous nation, the People's Republic of China, and the United States, are changed so that we are on the eve of what could be the greatest generation of peace, true peace for the whole world, that man has ever known.
 — From Richard Nixon's Remarks on Being Reelected to the Presidency, November 7, 1972. [Emphasis added.]

Nixon's Logic and Pragmatism

A president who calls for peace while ordering the Air Force to run bombing missions may seem enigmatic. In calling for peace with honor, Richard Nixon makes it obvious he disagreed with Benjamin Franklin's sentiment, expressed in a letter to his friend Josiah Quincy in 1783, that there never was a good war, or a bad peace.

Richard Nixon's preference for logic — represented by the Green in his spiritual portrait — along with his fervent anti-communism, would not let him agree to peace at any cost, despite the ongoing and intensifying emotional anti-war protests. Doing so would be considered weakness and imply a willingness to allow South Vietnam to submit to North Vietnamese aggression.

And Nixon's preference for pragmatism — represented by the Yellow in his portrait — caused him to order increases in the bombings when attempts to help the opposing sides reach agreement stalled. Bombs are facts that are impossible to ignore.

In one example of these pragmatic, destructive tactics, Nixon and Kissinger started seeing some breakthroughs in the peace process in 1972, yet encountered resistance from the President of the South Vietnamese, Nguyễn Văn Thiệu. To demonstrate his continued support for the South Vietnamese, Nixon ordered Operation Linebacker II, known as the Christmas Bombings, in late December of 1972.

Withdrawing the Troops

Richard Nixon supplanted these military efforts with diplomatic efforts — in addition to the peace talks — by pursuing detente with the Soviet and Chinese communist forces supporting the North Vietnamese. He also called for supplying military aid under Operations Enhance and Enhance Plus.

Nixon's determination and decisiveness — visible in his spiritual portrait in the predominance of Green — to achieve peace with honor finally prevailed in January of 1973 when the belligerents signed a peace treaty. Nixon ordered the withdrawl of all US troops from Vietnam, the combatants exchanged prisoners in February and March, and Congress passed the Case-Church Amendment in June of 1973, prohibiting further military involvement in the area.

This Is The End

After the withdrawl of troops from Vietnam, Nixon was increasingly plagued by the Watergate scandal. On February 6, 1974 the House of Representatives decided Nixon's role in covering up the malfeasance was enough for them to initiate impeachment proceedings against him.

A turning point came when the Supreme Court decided unanimously on July, 24, 1974, in United States v. Nixon, that he must relinquish the incriminating tapes recorded in the Oval Office.

Rather than continuing going through the impeachment process, Nixon gave his resignation speech on August 8, 1974, and left office at noon the next day.

There is one cause above all to which I have been devoted and to which I shall always be devoted for as long as I live.
When I first took the oath of office as President five and a half years ago, I made this sacred commitment, to consecrate my office, my energies, and all the wisdom I can summon to the cause of peace among nations.
I have done my very best in all the days since to be true to that pledge.
 — From Richard Nixon's Resignation Speech, August 8, 1974.

Peacemaker?

Although Nixon was able to extricate America from Vietnam, the war between North and South Vietnam continued. Further aid from the United States became impossible due to resistance by Congress, and Saigon eventually fell on April 30, 1975.

No event in American history is more misunderstood than the Vietnam War. It was misreported then, and it is misremembered now. Rarely have so many people been so wrong about so much. Never have the consequences of their misunderstanding been so tragic.
 — From No More Vietnams by Richard Nixon, 1987.

As a result of the troop withdrawl, Henry Kissinger and Lê Đức Thọ were awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1973. Thọ rejected the award and, after the Fall of Saigon, Kissinger tried to return it.

A More Modern Perspective

Putting Nixon's efforts in a more modern perspective is a declaration by Hunter S. Thompson — Richard Nixon's nemesis at Rolling Stone Magazine during the Vietnam War — in 2004:

Nixon was a professional politician, and I despised everything he stood for — but if he were running for president this year against the evil Bush-Cheney gang, I would happily vote for him.
 — Hunter S. Thompson, Fear and Loathing, Campaign 2004, October 20, 2004.

It takes more than one person to bring peace to the world. Richard Nixon was only human, and sadly, his efforts failed in the long run.

But it's important to realize that when it came to bringing peace to Vietnam, he did his best. And despite his foibles, Nixon certainly managed to save countless lives in his tireless pursuit of peace with honor and his successful negotiation of the withdrawl of America troops from Southeast Asia.

– –

Richard Nixon died at the age of 81 on April 22, 1994. A line from his First Inaugural Address — The greatest honor history can bestow is the title of peacemaker — was used as his epitaph.

About This Portrait

This spiritual portrait is based on the following videos:

  • the excellent American Experience video about Richard Nixon, October 15, 1990 (2:48)
  • the David Frost Interviews Richard Nixon, the original Watergate interviews, 1977 (1:25)
  • the movie Frost/Nixon, 2008 (2:02)
  • the documentary The Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers, 2009 (1:32)
  • the very enjoyable movie Elvis & Nixon, 2016 (1:26)

Other sources include the information found at all the links used to compose the story above and the countless impressions Richard Nixon made on me over the years, both during and after his presidency.
